nodes.bodyText: @guozhangwang  proposed just to call cache.flush() instead of flush(). I have not done that because in some caching state stores flush() is either synchronized or it contains locks or it neither the one nor the other. I wanted first to clarify on that before I make this change. So I guess flush() needs to be synchronized because of Interactive Queries on the underlying state store, right? Does the cache also need to be synchronized?
Why did you change the order of super.close() vs cache.close() ?

Why did you change the order of super.close() vs cache.close() ?

In CachingKeyValueStore, the order is as I did in this PR. So I wanted to make the order consistent across Caching*Store and thought this order is the one that makes more sense because I felt it is more important to close the underlying state store than the cache. But in the end, it doesn't make any difference.

But IIRC, it's dubious to throw exceptions in a finally block because it creates ambiguity about which exception should ultimately get thrown.

Makes sense.

because it creates ambiguity

AFAIK, it's not ambiguous: a later thrown exception would "overwrite" the former.
But it's better to collect all exceptions anyway.
Nit: Why not import Bytes?
Because it was late and I missed it ;-)
Should we verify regardless of the NPE?

I changed NullPointerException to RuntimeException (also due to the changes to not throw in a finally block). The test verifies that the underlying state store is closed if a runtime exception is thrown. I think that it is fine now.
Ok, I was just concerned that if the exception weren't thrown, we would be verifying nothing, and the test would pass silently, but if you prefer this structure, then I'm fine with it.
The missing piece is a unit test that verifies that close() of the underlying store is called when close() of the caching store is called.
Wait, there are tests that do that indirectly.
Not sure about this variable rename, since the CachingKeyValueStore is also a "keyValueStore". I.e., the important thing about the one we're declaring here is that it's the "underlying" one.
Ack
As we discussed offline, I think here we can just call cache.flush(cacheName) instead of this.flush right?
See my comment #8368 (comment)
Should we have a "global utility" class that unifies all helper methods we use throughout the whole code base? (Not in this PR thought, but as a follow up)

Yeah, I was thinking that, but didn't mention it for fear of expanding the scope of this PR. We could use such a utility all over the place when we need to capture exceptions in closing.
I'll send a follow-up PR.
I did this because I was trying to debug the "remove all sensors" method, and I needed to debug this method, but was unable to. I left the change here for the same reason.
Ack. Works for me (in fact, is like the code better after you change anyway :) )

We need to check again after we grab the lock, otherwise the store might get closed after we check but before we grab the lock. Once we get the lock, we're guaranteed that this block is serialized wrt close(). But we can still check beforehand to avoid grabbing the lock if it is closed.
Why would it not be sufficient to only check after we got the lock?
It would be sufficient. I assumed that we were checking before the lock to avoid synchronization overhead, so I left that in place.
They do the same thing, but the majority of calls are on wrapped().
This check means we don't have to construct the exception message string if we're not going to throw.
The check itself (ie, for isEmpty() makes sense) but I would still try to avoid the null
This is what @guozhangwang was asking for.
Like it!
I just plunked this class where it was needed right now; we can move it later if we want to use it elsewhere.

The rest of the exceptions are listed as "suppressed by" the exception we're throwing.
This is a related bug I fixed. It's basically the same thing, but for Metered store. There's no need to use the new util when we're just dealing with one potentially-throwing operation.
Why this rewrite?
I did this because I was trying to debug the "remove all sensors" method, and I needed to debug this method, but was unable to. I left the change here for the same reason.
Why do we  call this a second time? Also, it seems to be a very generic pattern for all method calls -- can we extract this in some private helper method ?

We need to check again after we grab the lock, otherwise the store might get closed after we check but before we grab the lock. Once we get the lock, we're guaranteed that this block is serialized wrt close(). But we can still check beforehand to avoid grabbing the lock if it is closed.
We can extract a helper, but maybe we can do that in a follow-up at least, since the concurrency controls needs to be standardized across all the caching stores anyway.
Ack.
These tests were missing, so I added them.
These tests are the ones that cover the bug I fixed.
Isn't this the same thing?
They do the same thing, but the majority of calls are on wrapped().
Compare my comment below. We should avoid returning null to avoid the necessity of a null check.
Why not make it final and return an empty list? It seems better to avoid using null if possible

nodes.bodyText: Same here: can we avoid potential null values?
Why not throw a general RuntimeException but a NPE?
This was Bruno's test; I just left them alone.
This was poorly stated, what I meant was that I was reluctant to change parts of the PR that had already been approved.
Why not use assertThrows ?

What do we actually test here? Closing the underlying store is the last thing we do, so it does not affect the happy path of flushing/closing the cache (what we verify at the end). Not sure what the value of this test is?
I see what you mean. IMO we should test also this, because tests are also here to make refactoring safe. Let's assume somebody changes the order of the closes, we would still have a check.
Do we need to validate twice before grabbing the lock? Maybe only the validation at line 283 is sufficient.

Matthias felt the same, and I also agree, but I'd like to do it in a follow-on PR. I was just quickly fixing a concurrency bug on the side, since I added synchronization to close expressly for the purpose of serializing closing the store wrt these methods.
https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/8368/files/c51b89b829dbd9f306f9c94e085f978155cc1eb3#r399572942
If an exception is thrown in cache flush / close, it means we would not trigger wrapper#close, which is different from the current trunk. Is that intentional?

iiuc, this is actually the bug that we are fixing here. On the current trunk, if flush or cache.close throws, we do not close the wrapped store. Now, with this change, we still call flush, cache.close, and wrapped().close, regardless if some of them throw.
Thx.
